repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Vernon Smith (born 1927) is a Nobel Prize winner and Professor of Economics and Law at Chapman University. This collection primarily documents his professional life through his correspondence, writings, research, teaching, and professional service. It forms part of the Economists' Papers Archive.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access restricted. Some materials in this collection contain potentially sensitive information. Contact Research Services for access.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access note. Some materials are electronic records that require special equipment. Contact Research Services with questions.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Vernon L. Smith papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book and Manuscript Library as gifts from Vernon Smith between 1996-2022.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Vernon L. Smith papers are arranged into six series: Correspondence, Personal, Print Material, Professional Service, Research and Writings, and Teaching.

eventgrp.event: Professor of Economics and Law and founding Director of Interdisciplinary Center for Experimental Science (ICES), George Mason Universiy (along with three colleagues from Arizona)

chronitem.event: Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences for his work on empirical economic analysis, especially related to alternative market mechanisms
Professor of Economics and Law, George L. Argyros Endowed Chair in Finance and Economics, and founder of Economic Science Institute (ESI), Chapman University

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Alvin Roth papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Duke University.
Raymond C. Battalio and John B. Van Huyck papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Duke University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The bulk of these papers reside in Research and Writings, which contains extensive files of his research notes, reprints, and revisions of working papers by himself and others with annotations. Broadly speaking, these files document important developments in experimental economics and his contributions to this field of study. Primary subjects include the development of a methodology for experimental economics; the implementation of experimental economics into the studies of asset trading, capital investment, game theory, environmental economics, price behavior, strategic decision making, and utilities; and the behavior toward, as well as the psychology behind, economic decisions. Print Materials includes reprints of journal articles by him on similar topics, many of which are also available through the library catalog.

Correspondence contains primarily professional communications concerning comments on his work by other economists, comments on other economists' work (dating from his days editing for several journals), and academic affairs (including recommendations and planning for classes and seminars). The contents of two emails accounts have been transferred and are available, and they contain tens of thousands of messages.

Professional Service and Teaching follow his activities as a faculty member at the universities of Purdue, Brown, Massachusetts, Arizona, George Mason, and Chapman; his roles with organizations such as the National Science Foundation, National Academy of Science, and the Journal of Economic Behavior; and his domestic and international consulting on utility regulation.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the Rubenstein Library's Citations, Permissions, and Copyright guide.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Some email files contain social security numbers. Restriction expires in 2077 or upon removal of SSNs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains mainly professional and academic correspondence, with the bulk from 1971-2007. Includes email from two email accounts--one George Mason and the other America Online (the GMU one also contains an export from Arizona, which is why it dates back to 1993).

Types of correspondence include: routine academic correspondence, including recommendations for students and faculty, as well as other academic affairs; works of other economists; correspondence concerning Smith's publications; some discussions of economic theory and applications; and professional correspondence, including non-academic recommendations and job offers.

Majority of the series falls into three main categories: comments on other economists' work, dating to his tenure as editor of several economics journals; comments from colleagues, referees, and other academics on his works; and academic affairs, namely recommendations and routine organizational letters dealing with classes and seminars.

Notable correspondence includes early exchanges with Paul Samuelson concerning Smith's thesis and graduate level coursework. Also, in one folder of miscellaneous personal correspondence at the end of the series (maybe box 24?), a colleague speaks at length in several letters about the Cuban crisis and civil rights protests.
Arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes folders for Jonathan Hughes, John E. Pfeiffer, Jean-Claude Schoenman, Alan Silberberg, and Henry K. H. Woo, as well as the years 2003-2018.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains Smith's academic coursework as a student; clippings; calendars and planners; personal correspondence; and vitae.
Academic coursework includes course notes, papers, and entrance and final exams from his time as a student at the California Institute of Technology.
Samuelson material concerns a seminar taught by Samuelson while Smith was pursuing a Ph. D. at Harvard.
Thesis appendix functions as an explanation of the theories in Smith's main text, utilizing the results of his economic work.
Clippings deal with the awarding of various professorships to him, and the Arizona Stock Exchange.
Interview, conducted for the book Economics in Our Times, explores the subject of experimental economics and his role in the study of it.
Arranged alphabetically by subject.

did.unittitle: California Institute of Technology, entrance exams, 1938-1946
Econ 304, development of economic thought to 1870, undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes agendas, minutes, financial records, and other documents from Smith's time on Board of Directors for Apex Microtechnology, a corporation based in Tucson, Arizona that manufacturers precision electrical components.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains operating agreement between Arlington Economics (AE) and founders Thomas Hazlett, David Porter, and Smith. AE is based out of Virginia and consults on experimental economics, telecommunications policy, environmental markets, electricity pricing, and antitrust.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes few bits of material related to Smith's service as Chair of Economists for Clark. Ed Clark was Libertarian Party's nominee for U. S. President in 1980.

did.unittitle: Memoir, Experimental Economics at Purdue, undated
Property and Environmental Research Center; universities

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes contents of personalized leather folder from Property and Environmental Research Center (PERC) and miscellaneous material from Chapman University (including draft grant agreement with Koch Foundation), University of Alaska Anchorage (including 1 8x10' of him), and University of Arizona.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes flags, notes, and inserts (loose and stapled in).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of two groupings: Clippings and Reprints.

Clippings was assembled by Smith and consists of newspaper and magazine articles on topics such as auctions, energy resources, experimental economics, fixed prices, government regulation, and the stock exchange.
Reprints consists of articles written by him or for which he was a contributing author.

Large portion of the reprints are from a series published by the Purdue University School of Industrial Management Institute for Qualitative Research in Economics and Managment, which later became the Purdue University Herman C. Krannert Graduate School of Industrial Administration, Institute for Research in the Behavior, Economic, and Management Sciences.
Arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes reprints from Purdue University, as well as other academic journals.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access note. Some materials are electronic records that require special equipment. Contact Research Services with questions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Arranged by subject: Games and Economic Behavior, Guest Lectures, Journal of Economic Behavior and Organization, National Academy of Sciences, National Science Foundation, and Presentations and Seminars. These are followed by single folders in original order.

Contains files on contributions Smith made to professional associations such as the National Science Foundation, the Journal of Economic Behavior and Organization, and the National Academy of Sciences, as well as to the teaching profession and other associations. Contents are varied and include information on guest lectures, seminars, and workshops given by him at both the high school and faculty level, conferences he organized, consultancy positions he held, and professional association committee work he undertook.

Other material on conferences that he attended can be found in the Research and Writings Series. Many folders deriving from his undergraduate and graduate teaching can be found in the Teaching Series. Because of the nature of his contributions to economics research, much of his work for or with government or non-profit organizations, such as his economic analysis of pollution and recycling for federal government agencies, is found in the Research and Writings Series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes itineraries, expense forms, papers, transparencies, and correspondence related to guest lectures/workshops/seminars given by Smith. Some folders clearly indicate that he traveled with his wife Candace, and there are locations across the U. S. and around the world (primarily Europe and Asia). Presentations and seminars in boxes 35-36 probably have material of a similiar nature but from prior to the 1980s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Image files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes files on the Economics Science Lab at the University of Arizona (including a 2004 legal settlement between Arizona and Smith and three of his colleagues) and National Science Foundation grant proposals.

Three boxes of writings by other economists and academics in related fields are present; these are arranged alphabetically by author's last name and overlap with the Game Theory and Strategic Interactions subseries.
The remainder of the folders are arranged alphabetically by subject.

Additional material may be found interspersed throughout the Natural Resources and Utilities subseries.

did.unittitle: Economics Science Lab; International Foundation for Research in Experimental Economics; Cybernomics

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes material related to a 2004 settlement between the University of Arizona (UA) and 4 former UA employees: Smith, Stephen Rassenti, David Porter and Mark Olson. In 1999, a whistleblower complaint alleged irregularities in the affairs of the Economics Science Lab (ESL), International Foundation for Research in Experimental Economics (IFREE), and Cybernomics, Inc (an indepedent consulting firm that developed computer software for economic and market analysis). This led to a university investigation and audit that found that the 4 researchers may have personally benefited from use of UA facilities and other resources on behalf of Cybernomics, in violation of university and regent policies. Cybernomics dissolved in 2003 and the researchers agreed to pay back a portion of their salary, but admitted no wrongdoing. All 4 ended up at George Mason University (GMU), where they founded a reorganized ESL--the Interdisciplinary Center for Economic Science (ICES).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Arranged alphabetically by subject: natural resources; utilities, electric; utilites, smart markets; and utilities, natural gas.

Material on natural resources includes proposals (mainly National Science Foundation) and research and writings dealing with issues of exhaustible resources (land, oil, and water) and resource preservation (recycling, waste accumulation, and Exxon Valdez accident assesment). Also includes material for Smith's book Economics of Natural and Exhaustible Resources.

Material on electric utilities concerns the regulation and deregulation of electric companies and consists of articles, charts, clippings, drafts, and proposals. The principal regions researched include Australia, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, and the United States (Alaska, California, Illinois, New Mexico, and especially Arizona). The bulk of the files deals with work conducted at the Economics Science Lab, but other partners in this enterprise include the Arizona Corporation Commission (ACC), Federal Energy Regulation Commission (FERC), National Economic Research Associates (NERA). Department of Energy (DOE), National Science Foundation (NSF), Goldwater Institute, and various nationalized electric companies and government agencies.

Material on smart markets concerns the network design for all utilities, but primarily electric and natural gas. Major folder groups deal with research conducted for the industry in Hungary and his book on smart markets.

Material on natural gas consists of data, drafts, and research for his work entitled Experimental Auction Exchange for Pipeline Transmission Networks. Research was conducted in conjunction with FERC and the Energy Information Administration (EIA).
Box 174 includes unsorted material acquired through the 2013 accession.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns the theory and institutions of auctions and bidding, with a focus on double auctions, Dutch auctions, English auctions, multiple unit auctions, and sealed bid auctions. Additional subjects include price controls and radio spectrum auctions.
Arranged in original order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes instructions, forms, and results of experiements. Mostly math and numbers (graphs/charts/tables; formulas/equations) compared to writing and words (let alone whole papers). Could probably be divided and placed under existing subject-specfic subseries by someone who knows more (such as experimental economics, price behavior, and game theory and strategic interactions).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily contains reprints of articles by others on various topics of interest to Smith, which largely parallels the rest of the series: experimental economics, game theory and strategic decision making, markets, and price behavior.
First two boxes are arranged alphabetically by author's last name. Remaining files are in original order.
Box 174 includes additional unsorted writings by others acquired with the 2013 accession.

did.unittitle: Isaac and Walker, Research in Experimental Economics

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Text files; "On The Suboptimality of Voluntary Public Goods Provisions" by R. Mark Isaac and James M. Walker.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes articles/chapters by Debreu, Durden-Smith, Hughes, Gordon, Malinvaud, Mendelson et al., Reiter, Spence, Hertwig and Ortman, Kimbrough, Levitt and List, Lopes, and Vickrey; a course pack for Competitive Decision Making from Raiffa; and publications of/from Fortune, Cato Institute, Heritage Foundation, and Immunology and Allergy Practice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Covers Smith's lengthy teaching career, which included stops at Purdue University, Brown University, University of Massachusetts, University of Arizona, George Mason University, and Chapman University.
Consists of two groupings: Courses and Departmental.
Courses includes assigned readings by himself and others, course notes, transparencies, student experiments and essays, exam subjects, class lists, and graduate advising information.
Departmental includes committee meetings concerning issues of honors candidates, fellowships, faculty, and promotion and tenure.
Arranged roughly chronologically.
Box 175 includes unsorted materials acquired through the 2013 accession.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes syllabi, readings, and student papers from ECON and LAW courses at George Mason and Chapman.

did.unittitle: Economic Systems Design materials; other proposals; general lecture notes
